It doesnt even make sense from a Greed perspective. When you do restructuring, it usually costs you more in the year you do it than you save in payrollbecause of severance, job placement services, higher unemployment insurance costs, etc. Then you consider the increases in turnover and reduced engagement, and the costs are even higher because youre spending more rehiring for roles youre keepingbecause people jump ship from being afraid of more layoffs, employees are less productive, etc. It makes way more sense to implement hiring freezes in which hiring require upper management approval and relying on churn to reduce headcount. Broad layoffs only really make sense if youre looking to axe a project entirely, and arent able to place workers somewhere else.

replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

We dont even have to guess at a timeframe or anything. Just take what you would put in intel and calculate your balance in a high yield savings account over the next 2 years by month. That is literally what you are aiming to beat minimum, otherwise its actually a loss for your risk and effort. Dont do options. If you dont understand options you can lose a lot of money. If you do understand options you can lose an everloving shitton of money. If you watch this sub a week or two youll see guys posting 50k, 100k, 500k losses. Options were originally intended as a way to hedge your positions, and most hedge funds and serious investors still use them for that purpose. It works something like this Say i bought 10000 shares of nvda a couple years ago. Its gone up huge, lets say i paid 10 a share and theyre worth 100 a share now. I could buy long dated like years puts betting on it going to 50 or less. The puts would be very cheap for me to buy because thats very unlikely to happen but now in case something terrible does happen and nvda does crash my puts will pay off and i wont lose everything. Basically like insurance for stock positions, if that makes any sense.

Some people actually do research and make educated guesses but yea, people in this sub are mostly just gambling. Dont do options to gamble like this. This is not what they were originally intended for.

I cut the cable in 2008 when my cablesatellite bill was above 300month not to mention the cost of the receivers. I couldnt justify 300mo for the volume and percentage of commercials I was forced to watch on live TV. My first streaming device was my Wii console and ultimately moved to Roku. Ive been an A La Carte viewer since and am still paying significantly less monthly than I was in 2008, and, unless I need to watch live News or an urgent Weather broadcast Im happy to watch my favorite shows a day or a month, season or year after the networks broadcast live. While I dont subscribe to Disney, Im a Hulu, Amazon Prime, Netflix, YouTube premium, Pandora premium, Paramount with Showtime Peacock commercial free, Apple TV subscriber. The bottom line is I never run out of commercial free great movies, series, shows, documentaries, music, concerts, and global news to watch at my leisure and schedule in addition, my two kids and grandchild can watch pretty much whatever they love commercial free for significantly less than a commercial dominated satellite or cable broadcast which require a subscription for the better and best content anyway Im not a big sports aficionado, so I dont subscribe to the NFL or MLB streams, but know enough people to watch a game with if I really want to. When you get used to watching what you want without constant commercial interruptions, it becomes very difficult and annoying to watch commercials every few minutes. At least for me.
Thats peace of mind, if nothing else

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like CSCO to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax CSCO would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of CSCO stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on CSCO stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on CSCO stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.
